ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Increased familiarity with sources related to ordination and theories of ordination in Chinese Buddhism. Better understanding of the development of theories of ritual in Western scholarship. Improved skills in translating texts and producing annotated translations.
Annotated translation, textual strata comparison, manuscript versions Medieval Chinese rituals, Western anthropology on rituals

How to produce a scholarly, annotated translation of a classical text. How to locate and make use of resources on the Chinese Buddhist Canon and other collections of classical texts. How to trace the textual history of a document, especially through the various catalogues of Buddhist scriptures.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No significant weaknesses to speak of. Materials (both primary and secondary) were interesting and engaging. Seminar structure was effective. Meeting room was not ideal, but that does not reflect on seminar itself.

Annotated translations as assignments, a good way to learn how to properly translate things; anthropology theories as a companion, easy to bring back to Western scholarly context. suggestion: Other than the translation assignments, for secondary readings, it is better for students to write a response before the discussion.

The course was excellently designed, with a high focus on a single text that allowed us to work deeply. There was also a wide range of secondary material presented, covering key scholarship on the topic of ritual.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. As above, the combination of primary and secondary sources was engaging and informative. Strongly recommend for any student interested in ritual theory or Chinese Buddhism.
For East Asian studies, Buddhist studies, etc.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in classical Chinese Buddhism.
